learnings.title: Interests, Positions, and BATNA/WATNA
learnings.bodyMd:
# Interests, Positions, and BATNA/WATNA

## Overview
Separate interests (why) from positions (what). Define your Best and Worst Alternatives to a Negotiated Agreement.

## Key Concepts
- Interests vs. positions: needs vs. proposals.
- BATNA/WATNA: fallback and worst‑case plans.
- ZOPA: zone of possible agreement where deals can land.

## Examples
- Position: 12‑month contract. Interest: predictable costs and support.
- BATNA: month‑to‑month with fewer features.

## Common Pitfalls
- Entering talks without a credible BATNA.
- Arguing positions instead of exploring interests.

## Summary
List interests on both sides. Strengthen your BATNA and estimate theirs to find leverage and realistic targets.

learnings.title: Issue Mapping and Scoring
learnings.bodyMd:
# Issue Mapping and Scoring

## Overview
Map all negotiable issues and assign scores to evaluate packages across multiple dimensions.

## Key Concepts
- Issue list: price, term, scope, risk, timeline, service levels.
- Scoring: weight issues; convert into comparable points.
- Trade‑offs: give on low‑value to gain on high‑value issues.

## Examples
- 100‑point model: price 40, term 20, scope 20, support 20.
- Compare packages by total score, not just price.

## Common Pitfalls
- Negotiating one issue at a time.
- Vague terms that resist scoring.

## Summary
Score multi‑issue packages to evaluate value holistically. Use the model to guide trades and proposals.

learnings.title: Reservation Price and Targets
learnings.bodyMd:
# Reservation Price and Targets

## Overview
Define your reservation point (walk‑away) and your aspirational target before talks begin.

## Key Concepts
- Reservation price: point at which you prefer your BATNA.
- Target: ambitious but realistic outcome.
- Bracketing: set asks to anchor above target while credible.

## Examples
- Price band: reserve at $X, target at $Y, open at $Y+Δ.
- Non‑price terms: reserve on liability caps or response times.

## Common Pitfalls
- No pre‑defined walk‑away.
- Targets set by wish, not market and BATNA.

## Summary
Write down your reservation and target points. Use them to resist pressure and structure proposals.

learnings.title: Negotiation Plan and Role‑Play
learnings.bodyMd:
# Negotiation Plan and Role‑Play

## Overview
Prepare a written plan and rehearse with a partner to test assumptions and responses.

## Key Concepts
- Plan: goals, issues, scores, BATNAs, opening, concessions.
- Role‑play: simulate counterpart tactics and objections.
- Debrief: refine answers, evidence, and tone.

## Examples
- Mock call with a teammate acting as a tough counterpart.
- Checklist: open, probe, package offer, summarize, next steps.

## Common Pitfalls
- Treating negotiation as improv.
- Rehearsing only your talking points, not likely counters.

## Summary
Document your strategy and practice it under mild pressure. Iterate based on gaps exposed in role‑plays.

learnings.title: Opening Strategy and Agenda Control
learnings.bodyMd:
# Opening Strategy and Agenda Control

## Overview
Set tone and structure early: summarize goals, propose an agenda, and anchor with a credible opening.

## Key Concepts
- First offers: anchor but remain defensible.
- Agenda: order topics to build momentum.
- Process agreements: how decisions will be made and by whom.

## Examples
- Open with joint goals and a 3‑part agenda.
- Provide a package offer to explore trades across issues.

## Common Pitfalls
- Letting the other side set an unfavorable frame.
- Opening with a single‑issue number.

## Summary
Shape the frame early. Use a credible opening and agreed agenda to guide a collaborative process.
